newsitem.title: FRANCE: FOCUS - France, Germany move to squash franc fears.
newsitem.headline: FOCUS - France, Germany move to squash franc fears.

text.p: France and Germany moved swiftly to stamp out fears of a franc devaluation on Thursday with a joint statement implicitly rejecting a call by former president Valery Giscard d'Estaing for a depreciation in the currency.

In the statement, French Prime Minister Alain Juppe and German Chancellor Helmut Kohl said they had reaffirmed in a telephone conversation on Thursday that the current franc-mark rate was in line with fundamentals.

Their statement appears aimed at trying to close a Pandora's box opened by Giscard d'Estaing when he questioned in a magazine article on Wednesday France's "stubborn" determination to keep the franc tied to the mark.
France, he said, should declare plans to take the franc into European monetary union (EMU) at a much lower level than it is now against the dollar -- implying a sharp fall against the mark.
This would revive growth and help bring down unemployment, running at a record 12.6 percent.

His comments, which weakened the franc on Wednesday and Thursday, paved the way for debate, not only about the traditionally taboo subject of the franc-mark exchange rate, but also about France's commitment to monetary union.
In their brief statement, Kohl and Juppe made a point of repeating their determination to launch a single European currency in 1999.

"They reaffirmed the commitment of France and Germany to launch Economic and Monetary Union within the timetable and convergence criteria fixed by the (Maastricht) treaty," the statement, released in both Paris and Bonn, said.
Traditional opponents of monetary union however rushed to jump on the bandwagon.

"Valery Giscard d'Estaing has hit the nail on the head by stating that employment is the absolute priority," Gaullist National Assemby speaker and former anti-Maastricht campaigner Philippe Seguin said on Thursday.

"Valery Giscard d'Estaing has put the debate on Europe back on the correct footing. The problem is no longer about whether we are going to have a single currency, but how we go about it. We cannot steer around that," Seguin told reporters.
Giscard d'Estaing's comments were the second time this year he has challenged the government's position on monetary union.
In January, he called for a softening of Maastricht treaty criteria for EMU on budget deficits to take account of weakening European growth.

And although he now wields little real political power, he nonetheless struck a chord in a country where the government is deeply unpopular and where people are quick to blame Maastricht criteria for weak growth and mass joblessness.

His comments on the franc came shortly after after former German Chancellor Helmut Schmidt, who with Giscard d'Estaing was a founding father of the European Monetary System, slammed the Bundesbank for its insistence of a strict application of Maastricht treaty criteria.
The joint Franco-German statement was issued on the same day as a meeting in Bonn between Kohl and Giscard d'Estaing.
